title: Null byte injection

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information: Hi , I would like to report an issue that I have noticed in `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in?invitation_token=` . I am not sure if this is a valid security issue , but I have decided to report it anyway and see what you guys think. #Details: - When you go to https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in?invitation_token=xxxx , you'll get a 404 page because `xxxx` is not a voalid invitation token. - But if you go to https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in?invitation_token=eda8fca985bc4d4ef21f269ed2a24951 , you'll get a 200 response with the regular login form and a link at the bottom saying `Back to invitation.` . I was trying to get XSS or open redirect through the `Back to invitation` link , but found a Null byte injection issue. - If you go to `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in?invitation_token=eda8fca985bc4d4ef21f269ed2a24951%00">

activities.message: Thanks for your thourough explanation. I agree that this doesn't seem to have any security implications. Consulting a team member with more expertise on the matter to see if this can have any security implications elsewhere.

Hi @zombiehelp54, thanks for your report. I checked it out and as far as I can see, there is not a null byte injection here. If it would've been a real null byte injection, the invitation token in the response would've been cut off after it, which is not the case. I agree that it would've been cleaner to show a 404 when the invitation token wasn't found (or already used), but there's no security risks here. Please let me know if you think I missed something here.

Hi @jobert , thanks for replying.
> I checked it out and as far as I can see, there is not a null byte injection here. 

Actually there is a null byte injection issue here due to the fact that adding `%00` *0x00* Null byte character after a valid invitation token doesn't get you a 404 page , but adding any character after the valid token without the null byte character gets you a 404 page. 
Going to: `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in?invitation_token=[valid_token]anything ` gets you a 404 page.
But going to `https://hackerone.com/users/sign_in?invitation_token=[valid_token]%00anything ` gets you a valid login page. 
This obviously means that there is a Null Byte injection issue with the code handling the `invitation_token` parameter. 
Commonly , it can be used for sql injection , but I couldn't get that because I believe you do some other checks.

> If it would've been a real null byte injection, the invitation token in the response would've been cut off

The invitation token gets cut off in the action attribute of the login form , just inspect the elements and you'll see that it gets cut off. 
I believe the invitation token does not get cut off in the link that says **back to invitation** because your code just directly sets its value from the url.
 If you check the code you'd probably see that that's what's happening. 

> I agree that it would've been cleaner to show a 404 when the invitation token wasn't found (or already used), but there's no security risks here. 

This is not about invalid invitation tokens nor about how clean your website works (it works awesomely btw) , it's about having a null byte injection issue with the code which is a security-related issue that should be reported and fixed , also your application does actually show a 404 page when the invitation token is invalid!!!
Hey guys , have you seen my comment ?
@zombiehelp54 Sorry, I missed that specific behaviour when I read you report initially. I'm still not sure if this is something we're going to fix, but I'll take another look.

Hi @zombiehelp54, I looked into this today and agree that it seems to be a null byte injection. However, I wasn't able to exploit this. I also checked other places in our code where this happens. The string is truncated at the null byte because we use a Postgres backend (through ActiveRecord). The SQL query that was executed when you'd pass in an invitation token with a null byte was something like `SELECT * FROM some_table WHERE attribute = 'abcdef'`. Instead of using `@invitation.token` in the subsequent view, we used `params[:invitation_token]`. Due to the injection, these to could be different because `params[:invitation_token]` contains the string with the null byte, while `@invitation.token` contains the string until the null byte.

Have you been able to exploit this?

Hi @jobert , no I was not able to exploit this either.
 I will give it another try when I get back home. 

Cheers.
@zombiehelp54 This should be fixed. Can you verify the fix? Thanks!
I confirm this issue is fixed now.
Hey @jobert , just for record. I believe this must have been vulnerable to SQL injection , but I wasn't able to exploit it maybe because of cloudflare protection or any other firewall.

@zombiehelp54, we keep CloudFlare's WAF only in "simulate" mode, so it doesn't block anything, just logs them for us to monitor. This is on purpose, as we want to make sure we're not just hiding some actual vulnerability. We don't use any other sort of WAF (again, on purpose), as we don't want to mask real vulnerabilities.

I just took a look at the code fix, and I don't see how this could have caused SQL injection at all, sorry.

This wasn't exploitable at all, and fixing this was already on our list (basically, improving the input validation for all our endpoints). As there was no direct security issue, we're only awarding HoF with no bounty.

Please do keep sending us reports, though. We're always happy to have new things to check out and possibly fix. Happy hacking!

Awesome , I thought this was exploitable since @jobert didn't mention anything about having any other technique other than `@invitation.token` to protect against sqli.

Thanks for fixing this and no problem about the bounty , it's a great honor to be listed on Hackerone hall of fame :)
